JAY RUNNERS DEFEAT
WASHINGTON COLLEGE
Eastern Shoremen Furnish little

VISITORS VERY WEAK

Two First Places
Outclassed and out-run in all
events the track team of Washington College visited Homewood
Saturday to be sent down in defeat by the Blue Jay runners in
the first home meet of the season by the score of_ 95 to 31.
The issue was never in doubt
after the first few races, while the
times of the various events were
rather slow due to the muddy
track.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 17, 1927

HOPKINS SENIOR_ GETS
COLUMBIA FELLOWSHIP
Leslie A. S. Harris, a senior, received word last week
from New York that he has
been appointed to the Victor
Baier Fellowship of.Columbia University for next year.
The award, which carries a
stipend of $1,000, will enable
Harris to carry on work toward a Master of Arts degree in English and the
school of mu§ic at Columbia.
The Baier Fellowship is
offered annually to college
graduates ,all over the country who have had training in
music in addition to the A.
B. degree.
'Harris was pianist for two
years in the Hopkins Musical Club. He is a member
of the Tudor and Stuart Club
and of the Sigma Tau Delta
fraternity.

ASSEMBLY
Students May Take Courses in Faculty
of Philosophy and Business Economics
With tInstructors' Consent

Carrying two important messages to the student body at last
week's assembly, Dr. Joseph S.
Ames, acting president of the university and dean of the college
faculty, emphasized significant
parts of the New Plan and urged
the advisability of keeping politics out of student elections.

BE GOOD, GOUCHER!
Boston has very little on Goucher. The town of the Lowells
and the Cabots refuses to allow its citizens to read such naughty
demoralizing books as "An.American Tragedy," but, we dare say,
it has never refused its budding young geniuses the right to seek
other outlets for their pent-up literary enthusiasm. And this
(alas!) is just what the Press Club of our fair sisters has done.
It has told all little G.oucherites that they may not, under penalty—
• - well, we're not sure just what the penalty is—to contribute to the
Black and Blue Jay.
..The edict, which was so nastily unchivalrous as to mention
the Jay specifically, said that Goucher girls might not contribute to
periodicals of which a prototype did not exist at Goucher. Poor
Atlantic Monthly! And what is more, the ruling seems to have
come about through the continued appearance in the Jay of drawings by Goucherites.
We appeal to the Press- Club to rescind this cruel and vicious
ordinance. What harm can there be in Goucher's helping to enliven and embellish the poor Jay? Certainly, it seems to us, glory
will accrue to Goucher rather than be detracted from her by these
contributions. We believe that the Club has erred, or at least has
been wearing smoked glasses. Let's all be friends: how about it?

FATHER BILL
The movement_ undertaken by the lacrosse team to secure
to "Father Bill" Schmeisser
• sufficient funds to present
_ a gift
that will be commensurate with his long service to the University
is one worthy of much commendation. "Father Bill", like "Pop"
Swindell, has given his time and his invaluable advice to the team
year after year, and has consistently declined to accept a salary
of any sort.
No wordy panegyric is needed to inform Hopkins people of
"Father Bill's" contribution to Hopkins' lacrosse success. That
• all know. We are glad to see that he is about to receive a tangible
indication of the high regard in which he is held on the campus.

YES and NO
There are beautiful scenes in Baltimore, if one forgets that
Baltimore is home; if one puts aside his naturally casual acceptance of familiar scenes, closes that take-it-for-granted unseeing
eye, and looks about him with the eagerness of a stranger or a
returning prodigal son. The method of achieving such an appreciative state is simple; fall in love in May, spend some soft, misty
evening with the object of your affections, and walk very slowly
home at midnight. Then, I warrant, you will see. Walk through
Eutaw Place, where stiff red tulips pierce the dim night with
awful loveliness, where trees hang new festoons of dusky lacy
leaves, where an iron swan spouts upright yvhispering water unceasingly from his slender throat ;—sit for a moment on a bench
and look, and drink the exotic very warming wine of Spring, and
night, and a city's old loveliness; for there is a charm in Eutaw
Place at midnight, when only an occasional motor car brings back
the .hideous remembrance of the maddening crowd, and over
one,—pervasive, subtle as the intangible sensation a whiff of lilac
brings, restful as death on a bed of crushed violet, or sleep on
the trembling fragrant bosom, of the heart's desire, while the
tumbling tumult of her hair brushes your weary eyelids, caresses
your forehead from frowns to. pleasant intangible dreamings-over one there creeps a quiet ecstasy of detachment, safety, peace.
There are many white stone steps in certain of the unique
"neighborhoods" of ffaltimore. In Spring they are rather cold
to sit on after sun-set, unless the damsel fetches a cushion;. but
they are invariably spotless (in certain neighborhoods) and made
of virgin marble,—or perhaps very respectably married marble,
for they have a staid and proper look—and their whiteness is cool
and restful to the eyes under the fluctuating light of street-lamps.
Above these lamps the green leaves hang. There is one such
combination that I love very dearly,—not because of anything
that occurred on the steps beneath it, but because* of its very
familiarity, because of the unfailing thrill brought by each
Spring's recognition of the same leaves hovering over the same
small flame. I have always thought of that particular flame as
without heat, because the eager foliage forever seems to woo it,
bending against its stolid impregnable globe with a graceful
sophisticated caress. The lamp never puffs in a tremor of excitement, nor do the gentle twigs sacrifice their poise, except occasionally when a passionate May storm whips their emotions to a
frenzy. . . . And the habit of adoration grows year by year, in
my romance self as well as in the soul of that romantic tree, so
that wandering wordlessly homeward at some tiny hour of a
Spring night, I unfailingly catch my breath at the ineffable cool,
clean, very green grace of the lea:yes, and the lambent hazy light
of the worshipful lamp.

DANSEUSE
You are a living lyric, a song incarnate.
I watch with avid eyes your every movement,
And drink the ecstasy that flows therefrom.
You are a statue by some ethereal Phidias
Who molded you of flawless form—
Then breathed the fire of life into your limbs.
THESE DO PERSIST
the bastard beams
born of the lamplight and the wanton moon
sprawl shamelessly across the wall
But walls recede. . . .
and You—
your face
and those same eyes
that erstwhile intimately spoke to mine—
these do persist
between the jostle of the taxis' whizz
and drunken voices
intruding upward from the city street.

DR. SWARTZ DELIVERS
SECOND LECTURE

See

Takes Up Astronomical and Physical
Evidence of His Beliefs

Dr. C. K. Swartz, Collegiate
Professor of Geology, presented
last Thursday the second of his series of four lectures . on "Fundamental Problems Concerning the
Relations of Science and Religion."
Again, the lecturer spoke to an audience of a size beyond the normal
capacity of the room.
In the previous lecture, Dr.
Swartz had devoted his time to a
definition of his terms (the mechanistic and vitalistic concepts), an assertion of his personal belief in the
latter theory and a promise of proof
of this view in seven points, which
would encompass astronomy, physics, biology, geology, morals, mind
and self-consciousness..
In this lecture, he used astronomy and physics for instruments of
verification. He pointed , outl that
the mechanistic mode of thought
had a precarious basis upon the assumption that the universe is eternal. His work was to shatter this
premise.

With June Week programs before the student body in circular

of post-mortem festivities.

John. Markle was elected

Student Council for the year

after the assembly on Thursday. According to a ruling
of the Council, the number
of votes polled by the different candidates cannot be
made public. The other
nominees for the office were
Smith, Gettemuller, Gould,
Ghent, Zepp, Young.

years in the Hopkins Musical Club. He is a member
of the Tudor and Stuart Club

fraternity.

BE GOOD, GOUCHER!
Boston has very little on Goucher. The town of the Lowells
and the Cabots refuses to allow its citizens to read such naughty
demoralizing books as "An.American Tragedy," but, we dare say,
it has never refused its budding young geniuses the right to seek
other outlets for their pent-up literary enthusiasm. And this
(alas!) is just what the Press Club of our fair sisters has done.
It has told all little G.oucherites that they may not, under penalty—
• - well, we're not sure just what the penalty is—to contribute to the
Black and Blue Jay.
..The edict, which was so nastily unchivalrous as to mention
the Jay specifically, said that Goucher girls might not contribute to
periodicals of which a prototype did not exist at Goucher. Poor
Atlantic Monthly! And what is more, the ruling seems to have
come about through the continued appearance in the Jay of drawings by Goucherites.
We appeal to the Press- Club to rescind this cruel and vicious
ordinance. What harm can there be in Goucher's helping to enliven and embellish the poor Jay? Certainly, it seems to us, glory
will accrue to Goucher rather than be detracted from her by these
contributions. We believe that the Club has erred, or at least has
been wearing smoked glasses. Let's all be friends: how about it?

FATHER BILL
The movement_ undertaken by the lacrosse team to secure
to "Father Bill" Schmeisser
• sufficient funds to present
_ a gift
that will be commensurate with his long service to the University
is one worthy of much commendation. "Father Bill", like "Pop"
Swindell, has given his time and his invaluable advice to the team
year after year, and has consistently declined to accept a salary
of any sort.
No wordy panegyric is needed to inform Hopkins people of
"Father Bill's" contribution to Hopkins' lacrosse success. That
• all know. We are glad to see that he is about to receive a tangible
indication of the high regard in which he is held on the campus.

YES and NO
There are beautiful scenes in Baltimore, if one forgets that
Baltimore is home; if one puts aside his naturally casual acceptance of familiar scenes, closes that take-it-for-granted unseeing
eye, and looks about him with the eagerness of a stranger or a
returning prodigal son. The method of achieving such an appreciative state is simple; fall in love in May, spend some soft, misty
evening with the object of your affections, and walk very slowly
home at midnight. Then, I warrant, you will see. Walk through
Eutaw Place, where stiff red tulips pierce the dim night with
awful loveliness, where trees hang new festoons of dusky lacy
leaves, where an iron swan spouts upright yvhispering water unceasingly from his slender throat ;—sit for a moment on a bench
and look, and drink the exotic very warming wine of Spring, and
night, and a city's old loveliness; for there is a charm in Eutaw
Place at midnight, when only an occasional motor car brings back
the .hideous remembrance of the maddening crowd, and over
one,—pervasive, subtle as the intangible sensation a whiff of lilac
brings, restful as death on a bed of crushed violet, or sleep on
the trembling fragrant bosom, of the heart's desire, while the
tumbling tumult of her hair brushes your weary eyelids, caresses
your forehead from frowns to. pleasant intangible dreamings-over one there creeps a quiet ecstasy of detachment, safety, peace.
There are many white stone steps in certain of the unique
"neighborhoods" of ffaltimore. In Spring they are rather cold
to sit on after sun-set, unless the damsel fetches a cushion;. but
they are invariably spotless (in certain neighborhoods) and made
of virgin marble,—or perhaps very respectably married marble,
for they have a staid and proper look—and their whiteness is cool
and restful to the eyes under the fluctuating light of street-lamps.
Above these lamps the green leaves hang. There is one such
combination that I love very dearly,—not because of anything
that occurred on the steps beneath it, but because* of its very
familiarity, because of the unfailing thrill brought by each
Spring's recognition of the same leaves hovering over the same
small flame. I have always thought of that particular flame as
without heat, because the eager foliage forever seems to woo it,
bending against its stolid impregnable globe with a graceful
sophisticated caress. The lamp never puffs in a tremor of excitement, nor do the gentle twigs sacrifice their poise, except occasionally when a passionate May storm whips their emotions to a
frenzy. . . . And the habit of adoration grows year by year, in
my romance self as well as in the soul of that romantic tree, so
that wandering wordlessly homeward at some tiny hour of a
Spring night, I unfailingly catch my breath at the ineffable cool,
clean, very green grace of the lea:yes, and the lambent hazy light
of the worshipful lamp.

DANSEUSE
You are a living lyric, a song incarnate.
I watch with avid eyes your every movement,
And drink the ecstasy that flows therefrom.
You are a statue by some ethereal Phidias
Who molded you of flawless form—
Then breathed the fire of life into your limbs.
THESE DO PERSIST
the bastard beams
born of the lamplight and the wanton moon
sprawl shamelessly across the wall
But walls recede. . . .
and You—
your face
and those same eyes
that erstwhile intimately spoke to mine—
these do persist
between the jostle of the taxis' whizz
and drunken voices
intruding upward from the city street.

DR. SWARTZ DELIVERS
SECOND LECTURE

See

Takes Up Astronomical and Physical
Evidence of His Beliefs

Dr. C. K. Swartz, Collegiate
Professor of Geology, presented
last Thursday the second of his series of four lectures . on "Fundamental Problems Concerning the
Relations of Science and Religion."
Again, the lecturer spoke to an audience of a size beyond the normal
capacity of the room.
In the previous lecture, Dr.
Swartz had devoted his time to a
definition of his terms (the mechanistic and vitalistic concepts), an assertion of his personal belief in the
latter theory and a promise of proof
of this view in seven points, which
would encompass astronomy, physics, biology, geology, morals, mind
and self-consciousness..
In this lecture, he used astronomy and physics for instruments of
verification. He pointed , outl that
the mechanistic mode of thought
had a precarious basis upon the assumption that the universe is eternal. His work was to shatter this
premise.

New Features Incorporated in Attractive Schedule Lower Cost
to Student

With June Week programs before the student body in circular
form, every undergraduate who
likes a good time, in nearly every
sense of the word, is beginning to
look over and beyond the final
exam hazard to the merry period
of post-mortem festivities.
The announcement of the events
is couched in terms of cold formality which fail to give any inkling of the quantity, quality, and
variety of whole-hearted pleasure
crowded into one enthusiastic
week of merrymaking.
June Week programs vary little from year to year, but the committee feels that, under the leadership of Thomas F. McNeal, several distinctive features place this
year's program in a class by itself.
An All-Hopkins Affair

MARKLE ELECTED TO
STUDENT COUNCIL
John. Markle was elected
Sophomore delegate to the
Student Council for the year
1927-'28 at the last meeting
of the Freshman Class held
after the assembly on Thursday. According to a ruling
of the Council, the number
of votes polled by the different candidates cannot be
made public. The other
nominees for the office were
Smith, Gettemuller, Gould,
Ghent, Zepp, Young.
